Award.AwardTitle: Modifying the floral microenvironment: elevational divergence in floral thermoregulatory mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Highly mobile animals can relocate to microhabitats that suit their thermal requirements when ambient temperatures are either extremely hot or cold, called thermoregulation. Plants however, are subject to ambient temperature conditions which can be detrimental to their reproductive success. This investigation will test whether high elevation populations of a wild perennial plant in the southern Colorado Rockies are locally adapted to cool temperatures, with mechanisms that increase flower temperature, whereas low elevation populations have adaptive mechanisms to lower flower temperatures under high ambient temperatures. The work will pinpoint the mechanisms by which flowers warm and cool their internal floral temperatures and test how variation in thermoregulatory ability impacts plant reproductive fitness and plant-pollinator interactions. This award will involve undergraduates at Clemson University in research in STEM fields through studies on how floral warming in local, charismatic spring ephemeral flowers impacts reproductive performance and pollination at the South Carolina Botanical Garden. As climates are changing globally and flowers continue to emerge earlier, this research will inform how plants will ameliorate thermal stress to maintain reproductive success. This work has important implications for the future of plant reproduction in both wild and economically important crop species.

Angiosperms have evolved various mechanisms to achieve floral temperatures that deviate from ambient conditions, ameliorating damage to pollen and ovules and promoting pollinator visitation. Research to date is biased towards examining mechanisms of floral warming in cold environments, limiting the understanding of local adaptation in floral thermoregulation across thermal gradients and providing few examples of floral cooling. Additionally, studies linking variation in thermoregulation with variation in both gamete viability and pollinator-attraction in field conditions are scarce. This study will first test for differences in floral thermoregulation between high and low elevation populations of a widespread perennial distributed across a large altitudinal gradient in the Southern Rocky Mountains. Using growth-chamber experiments, thermal performance curves for pollen and ovule performance will be generated, and mechanisms of floral warming and cooling will be pinpointed using a combination of time-lapse photography and reflectance spectrometry. Finally, geographic variation in selection on thermoregulatory ability will be determined by linking pollen viability, seed set, and pollinator visitation with variation in floral temperature in both high and low elevation populations. This work will elucidate the complex mechanisms of floral thermoregulation and the impacts of thermoregulatory ability on plant fitness. It will shed light on how flowering plants may cope with changing temperatures and advancing phenologies in changing climates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thermoregulation is critical for the persistence of wild and domesticated organisms under rapidly changing climates. The mechanisms of thermoregulation are well studied in animals and often involve behaviors like movement to suitable microclimates. Behavioral thermoregulation is less studied in plants which are rooted in their substrate. However, plant structures like stems and petals can move in response to environmental change and these changes in orientation can impact plant temperature. The reproductive structures of plants (flowers and the pollen and ovules contained within them) are sensitive to temperature extremes. Therefore, modifying the thermal environment of reproductive structures may benefit flowering plant reproduction in highly variable thermal environments. Additionally, pollinators can sense floral temperature and associate it with floral rewards. This project tested whether populations of a widespread plant along a 1000 meter elevation gradient in Southwest Colorado have evolved different floral thermoregulatory abilities. We also evaluated the mechanisms underlying floral thermoregulation and the impacts of thermoregulation on plant reproductive success and pollinator visitation to flowers. In South Carolina, Clemson University undergraduates conducted research on floral thermoregulation in the South Carolina Botanical Garden and provided educational outreach to Junior 4-H Naturalists.

Our key findings revealed that alpine flowers warmed up more during the day than those at lower elevation by absorbing more solar radiation. They did this by cupping their petals more when it was cold which focused light within flowers and warmed reproductive structures. High elevation flowers were also more sensitive to temperature fluctuations than low elevation flowers—cupping when it was cold and flattening when it was hot. The pollen from high elevation plants performed better at higher temperatures suggesting that floral warming may be adaptive for pollen performance. Pollinators at high elevation also preferentially visited warmer flowers when it was cold out at high elevation. This was supported using time-lapse videography of natural flowers and experiments with model flowers where we altered only floral temperature but no other floral traits. We also found that flowers that warmed up more at high elevation had more pollen removed from flowers. At low elevation we found that flowers that cooled down more had higher pollen viability. Together, selection from the thermal environment on pollen viability, and selection from pollinators likely both play a role in shaping the differences in floral thermoregulatory abilities between low elevation and alpine populations. 

Clemson undergraduate researchers developed a project at the South Carolina Botanical Garden to examine floral thermoregulation in an early spring-blooming plant that flowers under the leaf litter in forests of the Southeastern USA. Because it has relatives know to be endothermic (i.e., metabolically generate their own heat), and because it flowers during conditions of early spring, students predicted the flowers would warm substantially. Interestingly, they found that flowers instead cooled well below air conditions during high heat and that this cooling effect may be beneficial for pollen viability in this species. They coupled their research with hands-on educational experiences for Junior 4-H Naturalists. Clemson students presented their results to the Junior Naturalists and their parents, presented multiple posters, and published their work in a peer reviewed journal. 

Overall, this grant supported training for 4 undergraduate students, 2 graduate students, and one postdoctoral researcher. It supported 8 conference presentations, 5 peer reviewed articles, and one manuscript in review. This work provided novel information on how petal movements can shape floral temperatures, which could be increasingly important for plant resilience under changing temperatures, altered flowering times, and migration into new thermal environments.
